sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: In Brazil, left-wing candidate Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva has won the presidential election in a stunning comeback. The former president saw off the far-right incumbent Jair Bolsonaro. In a divisive campaign Lula won 50.9% of the vote. And with me now to talk about what all of this means for Brazil and internationally is our very own Jay Marques.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Jay great to have you with us. What does this moment then mean for the country, for Brazil?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: And talk to me about the significance as well about the swing back to the left here it's absolutely huge for the country politically Helena Lula da Silva as we all know was a is a very famous politician not just in Brazil but around the world and it's is the only man who's managed to get into the high office three times now with a very short margin this time around. But looking back at Lula's history he has a very rich history in which he was accused of corruption multiple times, he was arrested for it, his cases were overturned by the Supreme Court, but nevertheless it's a huge moment because Brazil is not, some say it's not just choosing a leader, but it's choosing its own path going forward.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Obviously President Bolsonaro's time in office has been marked by a lot of dividedness and hate to be fair. So it's an absolutely huge moment for Brazilians not just in Brazil but around the world obviously. Voting in Brazil is compulsory so it's interesting that 32 million people didn't show up to vote even though it's compulsory and that shows that for many people none of the candidates represented a viable choice and also there is some some fear of violence in exercising your democratic right so now going forward then we're going to be talking about looking at waiting for that transfer of power. What can we expect.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Inauguration is on the 1st of January. So we've got exactly two months between now and the transfer of power. Traditionally presidents they hand over to each other. The outgoing president hands over a president's presidential sash to the to the incoming president. But it's going to be interesting to see how that's going to happen because Bolsonaro and Lula, they don't look eye to eye. Even in the latest debates, they couldn't even stand next to each other. They don't look at each other. So that's going to be interesting to see with the ceremonial affairs that's meant to be taking place on the 1st of January. But in the next two months as well, it's going to be interesting to see how President Bolsonaro is going to react.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: There are hints that he wouldn't go easily.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: He hinted many times he didn't trust the electronic machines that we use in Brazil to vote.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: He attacked democratic institutions in Brazil, the Supreme Court, the Constitution itself.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: He's got some cases that he still has to answer to in attacking the Constitution itself. He's got some cases that he still has to answer to in attacking the Constitution itself.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: So next two months, very interesting.

A new tax on oil and gas companies is unlikely to pass through Congress, but Biden's call for one could raise Democrat prospects next week.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Iceland's prime minister has published her first novel.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Catherine Jakobsdottir is a big fan of crime fiction, so it's natural her first book should be a thriller.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: She penned the story, entitled Reykjavik, along with best-selling Icelandic author Ragnar Jónasson, best known for the crime series Dark Iceland.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: They started writing the novel during the pandemic.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Writing is a deep tradition in Iceland.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: One in ten people living there reportedly publishes at least one book in their lifetime.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: I have been reading crime fiction all my life, so it is kind of in my DNA.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: And I think every politician needs to have something to take his or her mind from the daily business of politics.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Crime fiction is very therapeutic.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: It's really about solving crimes and finding justice, so it's a very therapeutic genre for me.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Reykjavik tells the story of an unsolved case of a girl who disappeared without a trace 30 years ago on a small island near the Icelandic capital.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: A local reporter traces the events back to 1986 when an historic summit between Ronald Reagan and Mikhail Gorbachev was held in Reykjavik. TV host Egil Helgason introduced the book on his popular show.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Yes, it's a very pleasant read. It's somewhat reminiscent of Agatha Christie and the writers who don't have much violence in their books. This is a mystery, not a blood-dripping horror story.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: The thriller was published in Iceland on October 25th and is already topping the bestseller list.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: It's being translated into several languages and will hit the shelves around Europe from summer 2023.
